text: Isabella Helen Karle (née Lugoski; December 2, 1921 – October 3, 2017) was an American scientist. She was instrumental in developing techniques to remove plutonium chloride from a mixture containing plutonium oxide. She worked on the Manhattan Project during World War II. She was elected a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences in 1993. For her scientific work, Karle has received the Garvan–Olin Medal, Gregori Aminoff Prize, Bower Award, National Medal of Science, and the Navy Distinguished Civilian Service Award (which is the Navy's highest form of recognition to civilian employees). Karle was born in Detroit, Michigan. She studied at the University of Michigan. In 1942, she married Jerome Karle, a Nobel Prize winner.Jerome Karle: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 1985 , Nobel Prize. Accessed September 22, 2009. They had three children. Karle died on October 3, 2017 at a hospice in Alexandria, Virginia of brain cancer at the age of 95. ==References== ==Other websites== *2005 Video Interview with Isabella Karle by the Atomic Heritage Foundation Voices of the Manhattan Project Category:1921 births Category:2017 deaths Category:Deaths from brain cancer Category:Cancer deaths in Virginia Category:Scientists from Detroit
